awd_titl_txt: CAREER: A Tangible-Graphical Approach to Engage Young Children in Wearable Design
awd_abstract_narration:
Involving children in creative design and STEM experiences is critically important, even at an early age.  Wearable construction toolkits such as Lilypad have shown promise in attracting underrepresented groups to STEM, expanding perceptions of computing, and empowering users to create personally meaningful computational designs.  These tools, however, set a high bar to entry, especially for young children, by requiring some programming, an understanding of electronics and circuits, and manual skills like sewing.   This research will investigate new interfaces, techniques, and tools to enable children ages 5-10 to program, build, and use their own interactive wearables.   While the target age range is ambitious, spanning differences in cognitive and motor skills as well as educational experiences, a key focus of the work is to better understand how to increase the approachability of wearable design, even for young children, and to scaffold users into creating increasingly complex designs to match their ability level.  Project outcomes will inform future digital-physical kits for children, advance our understanding of how to engage children in computational thinking and construction, and contribute to the areas of wearable computing and interaction design for children more broadly.  While the immediate target community of this research is young children, the methods will have broader implications for maker tools in general.  Working with his partners, the PI will conduct "making" workshops and run case studies which will provide new opportunities for engagement in design and STEM.  These case studies will also allow children to showcase their designs publicly.  The PI will open source his artifacts, create and upload generally accessible videos to YouTube, and maintain a public website describing the work.

This research will explore new tools, techniques, and interfaces for overcoming key challenges that currently limit broader participation in wearable creation, particularly with young children, and evaluate new developmentally-appropriate approaches in a mixture of lab and field studies.  The project will introduce a tiered hybrid tangible-graphical approach to wearable design, wherein children build and program their wearable creations physically by using tangible plug-and-play modules.  For older children (ages 8-10), touchscreen interfaces will allow the creation of increasingly sophisticated designs through visual programming, debugging, and sensor-based programming by demonstration.  This empirical research will advance the growing area of programming approaches and creative design tools for young children, and will provide the first assessments of how young children build wearables, including what they want to build, how they approach the building process, how they use their own designs in their everyday lives, and skill development related to engineering and computational thinking.

por.por_cntn:
My NSF CAREER proposal had three major goals: first, to identify key outstanding challenges that limit broader participation in designing, crafting, and building wearable computational designs, particularly with young learners; second, to design and build new tools, techniques, and interfaces for overcoming these challenges and enabling new forms of wearable and digital-physical computational designs; third, to evaluate said approaches in a mixture of lab and field studies.

As my CAREER relied significantly on working with and running user study sessions with children (K-12) and having access to fabrication equipment and lab space, our research was significantly impacted by COVID-19. Thus, my group pursued a broader range of projects than originally envisioned but still focused on expanding digital-physical tools, inclusive computing, and study methodologies to work with youth. Below, we summarize key achievements.

Key Achievements:

  • MakerWear. We developed and evaluated the award-winning MakerWear—a wearable construction kit for children that uses a tangible, modular approach to wearable creation. MakerWear is composed of two parts: (i) single-function electronic modules that, when combined, create complex interactive behaviors, and (ii) a flexible, magnetic socket mesh that is either pre-integrated into clothing or attached post-hoc like a fabric patch. By manipulating these tangible modules, children can create a wide range of designs: a 'sound-reactive shirt' that changes color with music, a 'fitness tracker' that automatically counts and display steps, or a new game of 'laser tag' where children interact together through their designs. MakerWear earned the Best Paper Award at ACM CHI, the top conference in Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) and is  open sourced on GitHub.The lead MS student, Majeed Kazemitabaar, is now a PhD student at the University of Toronto; the secondary lead, PhD student Liang He is now an Assistant Professor at Purdue.

  • Educating students with new co-design practices in the classroom. With Professor Jason Yip and PhD students Wendy Roldan (now at Google) and King Jin Lee (now an Assistant Professor at Ewha Womans University), we studied how to incorporate co-design with children in university HCI/design courses. The overarching goal was to provide students with tangible learning experiences working with end-users unlike themselves throughout a design project to gain both formative and summative understanding. This work led to multiple publications, including an ACM CHI’20 paper honored with an Honorable Mention Award (Top 5%) and an ACM DIS’21 publication aslso receiving Honorable Mention (Top 5%). In short, this work contributes new findings on how HCI/design students prepare for, execute, and reflect on their remote sessions with children and how educators prepare students to conduct remote usability testing. We also document the advantages and disadvantages of incorporating remote usability testing in HCI education in comparison with in-person. 

  • Meta-review of accessibility research. With Professor Leah Findlater and PhD students Dhruv Jain (now an Assistant Professor at UMich), Emma McDonnell, and Avery Kelly Mack, we provided the first-ever large-scale literature review of the accessibility field. The work contributes (1) a characterization of current trends in accessibility research, including identification of areas that have received disproportionate attention, areas that are underserved, and patterns in how both disabled and nondisabled participants are included in the research; (2) complementary temporal patterns from 1994-2019, particularly in terms of paper counts and communities studied; (3) reflections and recommendations to guide future accessibility research, identifying opportunities for growth and methodological decisions to question; (4) an open-source dataset and analysis scripts of accessibility papers (see GitHub). This work was published at ACM CHI’21 and earned a Best Paper Honorable Mention (Top 5%). Moreover, it is one of the top cited accessibility papers in the last few years (159 citations) with citations crediting our work with opening new directions in the field.

  • Digital-physical design tools for kinetic fabrication. With my PhD student Liang He, we pursued a multi-year research agenda around how to create design tools that support kinetic 3D printable objects. We first designed and evaluated Ondulé—an interactive design tool that allows novices to create parameterizable deformation behaviors in 3D-printable models using helical springs and embedded joints (published at UIST’19). As follow-up work, we created Kinergy—an open-source interactive design tool to create, control, and print 3D objects with self-propelled motion (published at UIST’22). Together, 3D printable kinematics opens new exciting opportunities for 3D printing: designers can create and control printable movement enabling a wide variety of applications from 3D printable rotational solar system models to robotic quadrupeds.   

  • Automatic indoor accessibility assessment. Finally, my PhD student Xia Su is leading a new initiative to combine real-time computer vision, LiDAR scanning, and 3D reconstruction to semi-automatically assess the accessibility of indoor spaces for people with disabilities. Although still early work funded towards the end of my CAREER, we have published both a workshop paper and more recently, a CHI’24 paper on a new open-source tool called RASSAR: Room Accessibility and Safety Scanning in Augmented Reality. See GitHub.
